topic.title: start
topic.shortdesc: Start servers, locators, gateway senders and gateway receivers, and monitoring tools.

topic.title: start gateway-receiver
topic.shortdesc: Start the gateway receiver on a given member or group of members.

body.p: Note that you can only have one gateway receiver on each member, and unlike a gateway sender, you do not need to specify an identifier for the gateway receiver.
Availability: Online. You must be connected in gfsh to a JMX Manager member to use this command.

row.entry: Name
Description
Name or ID of the member on which to start the Gateway Receiver.
Group(s) of members on which to start the Gateway Receiver.

body.codeblock:
gfsh>start gateway-receiver Member | Result | Message --------------------------- | -------| ----------------------------------------------------------------------- pc13(2266)<v6>:56852 | OK | GatewayReceiver is started on member pc13(2266)<v6>:56852 pc13(Manager:2242)<v5>:57631| Error | GatewayReceiver is not available on member pc13(Manager:2242)<v5>:57631 pc13(2275)<v7>:47480 | OK | GatewayReceiver is started on member pc13(2275)<v7>:47480 pc13(2293)<v8>:55472 | OK | GatewayReceiver is started on member pc13(2293)<v8>:55472
gfsh>start gateway-receiver --member=pc13(2266)<v14>:36579 GatewayReceiver is started on member pc13(2266)<v14>:36579
gfsh>start gateway-receiver --group=RG1 Member | Result | Message -------------------- | -------| ---------------------------------------------------------- pc13(2275)<v23>:27484| OK | GatewayReceiver is started on member pc13(2275)<v23>:27484 pc13(2293)<v24>:55810| OK | GatewayReceiver is started on member pc13(2293)<v24>:55810 pc13(2266)<v22>:4522 | OK | GatewayReceiver is started on member pc13(2266)<v22>:4522

topic.title: start gateway-sender
topic.shortdesc: Start the gateway sender on a member or members.

body.p: For information on how to configure a gateway sender, see .
Availability: Online. You must be connected in gfsh to a JMX Manager member to use this command.

row.entry: Name
Description
Required. ID of the GatewaySender.
Group(s) of members on which to start the Gateway Sender.
Member used to start the Gateway Sender

body.codeblock: start gateway-sender --id=sender1-NY start gateway-sender --id=sender1-NY --member=server1 start gateway-sender --id=sender1-NY --group=MemberGroup1,MemberGroup2

gfsh>start gateway-sender --id=ln Member | Result | Message ------------------------------| ------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------- pc13(30614)<v6>:63670 | OK | GatewaySender ln is started on member pc13(30614)<v6>:63670 pc13(30621)<v7>:36015 | OK | GatewaySender ln is started on member pc13(30621)<v7>:36015 pc13(30633)<v8>:13633 | OK | GatewaySender ln is started on member pc13(30633)<v8>:13633 pc13(Manager:30588)<v5>:42792 | Error | GatewaySender ln is not available on member pc13(Manager:30588)<v5>:42792
gfsh>start gateway-sender --id=ln --member=pc13(30614)<v14>:44519 GatewaySender ln is started on member pc13(30614)<v14>:44519 gfsh>start gateway-sender --id=ln --group=SenderGroup1 Member | Result| Message ---------------------- | ------| ------------------------------------------------------------ pc13(30614)<v18>:15201 | OK | GatewaySender ln is started on member pc13(30614)<v18>:15201 pc13(30621)<v19>:61437 | OK | GatewaySender ln is started on member pc13(30621)<v19>:61437 pc13(30633)<v20>:22567 | OK | GatewaySender ln is started on member pc13(30633)<v20>:22567

topic.title: start jconsole
topic.shortdesc: Start the JDK JConsole monitoring application in a separate process.

body.p: JConsole automatically connects to a running JMX Manager node if one is available.
Note that you must have a JDK installed (not just a JRE) and the correct PATH and JAVA_HOME environment variables set.
See for an example of using JConsole with the management and monitoring system.

row.entry: Name
Description
Default Value
Set the update interval to n seconds (default is 4 seconds). (Equivalent to JConsole's -interval=n)
Whether to initially tile windows for two or more connections. This parameter is passed as -notile to JConsole.
false

"Directories or JAR files which are searched for JConsole plugins. The path should contain a provider-configuration file named:\n" + " META-INF/services/com.sun.tools.jconsole.JConsolePlugin\n" + "containing one line for each plugin specifying the fully qualified class name of the class implementing the com.sun.tools.jconsole.JConsolePlugin class."
Display the JConsole version information. This parameter is passed as -version to JConsole.
false
Arguments passed to the JVM on which JConsole runs

body.p: The JConsole application appears and auto-connects to a JMX Manager node if one is available:
body.codeblock:
An error occurred while launching JConsole = %1$s
Connecting by the member's name or ID is not currently supported. Please specify the member as '<hostname|IP>[PORT].
An IO error occurred while launching JConsole. Please ensure that JAVA_HOME is set to the JDK installation or the JDK bin directory is in the system PATH.
JConsole could not be found.\nPlease ensure that JAVA_HOME is set to the JDK installation or the JDK bin directory is in the system PATH.

topic.title: start jvisualvm
topic.shortdesc: Start the JDK's Java VisualVM monitoring application in a separate process.

row.entry: Name
Description
VM-option passed to the spawned CacheServer VM. For example: -J-Dfoo.bar=true for setting foo.bar to 'true'.

body.p: The command creates a subdirectory and log file named after the locator. If the locator detects that no other JMX Manager exists, then the locator will automatically start an embedded JMX Manager and connect the current gfsh session to the JMX Manager.

p.note: You must have JAVA_HOME set before starting gfsh to use this command.

body.p: In addition, if gfsh is not already connected to a JMX Manager, the gfsh console will automatically connect to the new embedded JMX Manager started by the new locator.

p.note: When both --max-heap and --initial-heap are specified during locator startup, additional GC parameters are specified internally by 's Resource Manager. If you do not want the additional default GC properties set by the Resource Manager, then use the-Xms and -Xmx JVM options. See for more information.

row.entry: Name
Description
Default Value
Required. Name to be used for this locator service.
IP address on which the locator will be bound.
bound to all addresses
Whether to allow the PID file from a previous locator run to be overwritten.
false
Group(s) the locator will be a part of.
Hostname or IP address that will be sent to clients so they can connect to this locator.
uses the bind-address to which the locator is bound).
List of locators used by this locator to join the appropriate cluster.
Level of output logged to the locator log file. Possible values for log-level include: finest, finer, fine, config, info, warning, severe, none.
IP address or hostname used to bind the UPD socket for multi-cast networking so the locator can locate other members in the cluster. If mcast-port is zero, then mcast-address is ignored.
Port used for multi-cast networking so the locator can locate other members of the cluster. A zero value disables mcast.
Port the locator will listen on.
Directory in which the Locator will be started and run.
Specify the gemfire.properties file for configuring the locator's distributed system. The file's path should be absolute or relative to gfsh's working directory.
The gfsecurity.properties file for configuring the Locator's security configuration in the distributed system. The file's path can be absolute or relative to gfsh's working directory.

Size has the same format as the -Xmx/-Xms JVM options. If you use the -J-Xms and -J-Xmx JVM properties instead of -initial-heap and -max-heap, then does not use default JVM resource management properties. If you use the JVM properties, you must then specify all properties manually for eviction, garbage collection, heap percentage, and so forth.

Size has the same format as the -Xmx/-Xms JVM options If you use the -J-Xms and -J-Xmx JVM properties instead of -initial-heap and -max-heap, then does not use default JVM resource management properties. If you use the JVM properties, you must then specify all properties manually for eviction, garbage collection, heap percentage, and so forth.
When connect is set to false, gfsh does not automatically connect to the locator which is started using this command.
true
Enables cluster configuration behavior where locators maintain configurations for all members of a distributed system. See .
true

Loads the cluster configuration from the shared-config directory. (When set to false, the configuration is loaded from the disk store of the internal, persistent region used by the locator to persist the configuration.)
false
Directory used by the cluster configuration service to store the cluster configuration on the filesystem
cluster-config

Argument passed to the JVM on which the Locator will run. For example, specifying --J=-Dfoo.bar=true sets property "foo.bar" to "true".
If the argument you are passing contains spaces or commas, enclose the option in single quotes. For example:start locator --name=locator1 --port=9009 --mcast-port=0\ --J='-Dgemfire.remote-locators=10.116.34.222[9009],10.116.35.225[9009]'
none

body.codeblock:
gfsh>start locator --name=locator3 Starting a GemFire Locator in /home/stymon/locator3... ................................ Locator in /home/stymon/locator3 on ubuntu.local[10334] as locator3 is currently online. Process ID: 1898 Uptime: 19 seconds GemFire Version: 8.0.0 Java Version: 1.7.0_65 Log File: /home/stymon/locator3/locator3.log JVM Arguments: -Dgemfire.default.locators=192.168.129.145[40402] -Dgemfire.enable-cluster-configuration=true -Dgemfire.load-cluster-configuration-from-dir=false -Dgemfire.launcher.registerSignalHandlers=true -Djava.awt.headless=true -Dsun.rmi.dgc.server.gcInterval=9223372036854775806 Class-Path: /home/stymon/Pivotal_GemFire_800_b48258_Linux/lib/locator-dependencies.jar: /usr/local/java/lib/tools.jar
Cluster configuration service is up and running.

topic.title: start pulse
topic.shortdesc: Launch the Pulse monitoring dashboard tool in the user's default system browser and navigates the user to the landing page (login page).

body.p: For more information on Pulse, see .

row.entry: Name
Description
Default
URL of the Pulse Web application

body.p: Sample Output: See for examples of Pulse.

p.note: When both --max-heap and --initial-heap are specified during locator startup, additional GC parameters are specified internally by 's Resource Manager. If you do not want the additional default GC properties set by the Resource Manager, then use the -Xms and -Xmx JVM options. See for more information.

row.entry: Name
Description
Default Value
Required. Member name for this Cache Server service.
Whether to assign buckets to the partitioned regions of the cache on server start.
false
The IP address on which the Server will be bound.
binds to all addresses
Specifies the name of the XML file or resource to initialize the cache with when it is created.
Location of user classes required by the Cache Server. This path is appended to the current CLASSPATH.
When true, include the System CLASSPATH on the Server's CLASSPATH, as the System CLASSPATH is not included by default. If specified without a value, the value is set to true.
false
Whether the cache server will be started by default. If the parameter is specified without a value, the value is set to true. If set to true, the cache server acts as a peer.
false
Prevents the JVM from exiting when an OutOfMemoryError occurs.
false
Causes additional time-based statistics to be gathered for operations.
true
The gemfire.properties file for configuring the Cache Server's distributed system. The file's path can be absolute or relative to the gfsh working directory.
The gfsecurity.properties file for configuring the Server's security configuration in the distributed system. The file's path can be absolute or relative to gfsh directory.
Group(s) the Cache Server will be a part of.
Whether to allow the PID file from a previous Cache Server run to be overwritten.
false
Sets the list of locators used by the Cache Server to join the appropriate cluster.
Sets the number of seconds the server will wait for a locator to become available during startup before giving up.
Sets the level of output logged to the Cache Server log file. Possible values for log-level include: finest, finer, fine, config, info, warning, severe, none.
The IP address or hostname used to bind the UDP socket for multi-cast networking so the Cache Server can locate other members in the cluster. If mcast-port is zero, then mcast-address is ignored.
Sets the port used for multi-cast networking so the Cache Server can locate other members of the cluster. A zero value disables mcast.
If specified and is non-zero, sets the port number for an embedded Gemcached server and starts the Gemcached server.
Sets the protocol used by an embedded Gemcached server. Valid values are BINARY and ASCII. If you omit this property, the ASCII protocol is used.
IP address on which the Server will be bound.
binds to all addresses
Port the Server will listen on for client connections.

Specifies the location of a Spring XML configuration file(s) for bootstrapping and configuring a Server. This configuration file can exist on the CLASSPATH (default) or any location supported by Spring's Resource(Loader) location specifiers (for example, classpath:, file:, etc). ResourceLoader is described in the Spring documentation.
Whether to initiate rebalancing across the cluster.
false
Specify the directory in which the server will run in. This directory is written to the location where you started gfsh.
If not specified, the directory is named after the server.
The file that statistic samples are written to. An empty string (default) disables statistic archival.

Initial size of the heap in the same format as the JVM -Xms parameter. If you use the --J=-Xms and --J=-Xmx JVM properties instead of --initial-heap and --max-heap, then does not use default JVM resource management properties. If you use the JVM properties, you must then specify all properties manually for eviction, garbage collection, heap percentage, and so forth.

Maximum size of the heap in the same format as the JVM -Xmx parameter. If you use the --J=-Xms and --J=-Xmx JVM properties instead of --initial-heap and --max-heap, then does not use default JVM resource management properties. If you use the JVM properties, you must then specify all properties manually for eviction, garbage collection, heap percentage, and so forth.

Argument passed to the JVM on which the Cache Server will run. For example, --J=-Dfoo.bar=true will set the property "foo.bar" to "true".
If the argument you are passing contains spaces or commas, enclose the option in single quotes.
Specifies whether the server requests a cluster configuration from the locator. See .
true

Set the percentage of heap at or above which the cache is considered in danger of becoming inoperable due to garbage collection pauses or out of memory exceptions. Past the threshold, operations that require heap space will throw a LowMemoryException. This feature requires additional VM flags to perform properly; you must set --initial-heap and --max-heap or the corresponding JVM properties to use this threshold. You must also set --max-heap and --initial-heap to the same value.
0 (no critical heap threshold enforced)

The percentage of off-heap memory used at or above which the cache is considered in danger of becoming inoperable due to out of memory exceptions. Past the threshold, operations that require heap space will throw a LowMemoryException.
0 (no critical off-heap threshold enforced)

Set the percentage of heap at or above which the eviction should begin on Regions configured for HeapLRU eviction. Changing this value may cause eviction to begin immediately. Only one change to this attribute or critical heap percentage will be allowed at any given time and its effect will be fully realized before the next change is allowed. This feature requires additional VM flags to perform properly; you must set --initial-heap and --max-heap or the corresponding JVM properties to use this threshold. You must also set --max-heap and --initial-heap to the same value.

ul.li: 0, if no region is configured with heap eviction
If critical-heap-percentage is set to a non-zero value, 5% less than that value.

row.entry: The percentage of off-heap memory used at or above which the eviction should begin on regions configured for off-heap and HeapLRU eviction. Changing this value may cause eviction to begin immediately. Only one change to this attribute or critical off-heap percentage will be allowed at any given time, and its effect will be fully realized before the next change is allowed.

ul.li: 0, if no region is configured with heap eviction
If critical-off-heap-percentage is set to a non-zero value, 5% less than that value.

row.entry: Sets the ip address or host name that this cache server is to listen on for client connections. Setting a specific hostname-for-clients causes server locators to use this value when telling clients how to connect to this cache server. This is useful in the case where the cache server may refer to itself with one hostname, but the clients need to use a different hostname to find the cache server. The value "" causes the bind-address to be given to clients. A null value will be treated the same as the default "".
Sets the maxium number of client connections allowed. When the maximum is reached the cache server will stop accepting connections
Sets the time (in seconds ) after which a message in the client queue will expire.
Sets maximum number of messages that can be enqueued in a client-queue.
Sets the maxium number of threads allowed in this cache server to service client requests. The default of 0 causes the cache server to dedicate a thread for every client connection.
Sets the buffer size in bytes of the socket connection for this CacheServer. The default is 32768 bytes.

(Linux only) When true, the member's heap and off-heap memory are locked in RAM, preventing them from being paged to disk. You must increase the related ulimit operating system resource to allow the OS to lock memory chunks of sufficient size.
false

The integer quantity of off-heap memory to be used for storing region values. Specified in Gigabytes with a 'g' suffix, or Megabytes with an 'm' suffix. For example, allocate a 2 Gigabyte off-heap space with --off-heap-memory-size=2g. The default value of 0 does not use any off-heap memory.

section.title: Examples
section.codeblock: gfsh>start server --name=server1 --server-port=40406 Starting a GemFire Server in /home/stymon/server1... .................................................... Server in /home/stymon/server1 on ubuntu.local[40406] as server1 is currently online. Process ID: 32209 Uptime: 47 seconds GemFire Version: 8.0.0 Java Version: 1.7.0_65 Log File: /home/stymon/server1/server1.log JVM Arguments: -Dgemfire.default.locators=192.168.129.145[40402] -Dgemfire.use-cluster-configuration=true -XX:OnOutOfMemoryError="kill -9 %p" -Dgemfire.launcher.registerSignalHandlers=true -Djava.awt.headless=true -Dsun.rmi.dgc.server.gcInterval=9223372036854775806 Class-Path: /home/stymon/Pivotal_GemFire_800_b48258_Linux/lib/server-dependencies.jar:/usr/local/java/lib/tools.jar
